pros: There are a great array of people from all of the world, both student and faculty. I find great connections and opportunities available, and it is readily out there if you look even a little bit.
cons: During your time as a student it may seem like all your hard work is without a goal. Regardless most the work ends up being a build of character and helps you in the end.

pros: There are over 5,000 research faculty at Georgia Tech committed to improving the human condition and working to find solutions to local and global challenges.  Georgia tech is a great learning environment with accessible professors and instructors and offers a large number of research scientist positions
cons: The work environment at Georgia Tech is very competitive and the work-life balance heavily leans toward work.  In some cases work is life.

pros: Good academia environment. Beautiful campus. Good facilities. People are nice. Georgia Tech is ranked among the world's best universities. Based in Atlanta, the large, public university. Many clubs you can join.
cons: Too much male and few girls. Payment is OK to low. Food is OK but not so good. And most of the time, campus has too much event with additional parking fee.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Students get paid easily and also receive tuition waiver. Tuition is tons of money for out-of-state student. Therefore, it it very worth to take the TA position. Also, it is also pretty interesting to answer questions.
cons: The workload is absolutely not small. You may expect the workload is equal to or even heavier than you actually taking a course.

review_title: Grad School - High Stress High Reward
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Interesting projects to work on
- Intelligent professors who can share skills and knowledge
- Beautiful campus in central Atlanta
- Prestigious place to get a degree
cons:
- High stress level pretty much whatever you study
- Professors and other students are too busy to care about supporting eachother

review_title: The large College of Computing provides many benefits and some downsides for PhD students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant, CoC in Atlanta, GA
pros: Nice, new facilities; many top-rate professors to work with; relatively easy to get and maintain funding as a grad student; many courses to pick from.
cons: It is easy to get lost (in a research sense) in such a huge place. The College of Community administration puts on various events to create a sense of grad student community, but it is not as strong as some other institutes.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: The compensation is definitely higher than other Universities and there are tons of advancement opportunities outside of your department if you are lucky. Job security part.
cons: The Parking situation sucks for Employees because it is very costly. The politics of working for the state make it so exhausting. You don't have any of the fun perks and bonuses you would get working for a private organization.

pros: Flexibility in work hours. Opportunities to take classes and earn a graduate degree. Opportunities to work on various projects.
cons: Compensation. Lack of definitive career advancement opportunities.The bureaucracy can weigh people down. Sometimes things move slowly for no good reason.

pros: free housing, lots of interaction with college students, gain leadership experience, close knit teams of residential advisors, programming and conflict resolution training
cons: a lot of work, very low pay, and a lot of long nights on duty where you are not guaranteed a full night of sleep

review_title: First and foremost an institute of technology
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Excellent Faculty
Cutting Edge Research
A heaven for introverts
cons:
Student to Faculty ratio is very high
Forget social life

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: very good research groups around here, awesome faculty, great atmosphere and facilities around, strong phd students to collaborate with and learn a lot.
cons: atlanta location does not have too many happening places or tourist spots in the city. The city looks kinda dull sometimes.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: R1 research university, really great opportunities to get into cutting edge research and learn latest techniques in a huge variety of fields,
cons: Graduate student fees are ridiculous, and they intentionally hide them from you until you start your first day of class and then hit you with them, your effective salary will be several thousand less than what they tell you, it was worse when I started and its getting better lately, but still outrageous

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great education taught by caring and intelligent professors. Plenty of research opportunities- both at the university and from collaborators who reach out constantly.
cons: Some PIs are not the most helpful and even try to kick out their students. They also try to force specific projects on students even after they agreed to let them work on a specific project before attending. Be wary and ask students not in the PIs research group about their reputation.

review_title: The place to work, the place to learn, the place to advance
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: There is no shortage of challenging problems and equally no shortage of resources to help you solve them. If you like working on challenging problems, this is the place.  Plus one can easily leverage the skills that you learn here and apply it to any other field at the end of your tenure.
cons: At times, an individual's ego can get in the way of progress.

review_title: It is a great place to work.
pros:
Great People
Great Students
The state of the art facilities make everything more enjoyable.  Midtown Atlanta is bustling with things to do.
cons:
The traffic coming to work and going home from work is awful sometimes.  
The crime incidences are increasing.  You must be careful where you go at night.

pros: Great faculty for student employees. The faculty and graduate students in the chemical engineering department are eager to teach the students and help them past graduation.
cons: Minimal payment ($10/hr) no matter how long you have been working in your lab. I also believe that there is a 10 or 20 hour maximum that you can work, limiting your paycheck.

pros: Georgia Tech offers unlimited opportunities for professional development: credit courses, noncredit courses, seminars, workshops, conferences, webinars, and more. Continuous professional development is highly stressed and employees are granted the opportunity to take full advantage of those learning opportunities.
cons: Like any large institution, sometimes the bureaucracy limits the rate of innovation and constrains employee initiatives at times, but not unduly so.

job_title: ECE User Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Great management
- Awesome Hours
- Flexible work times to accommodate school schedules
- Co-workers are friendly and in similar classes as you are.
Overall, this job did not add any stress to my schedule and I believe that it actually improved schedule by filling in waiting times between classes.
cons: I do not have any complaints for this job.  I am grateful for the opportunity to learn new things and have structure in my schedule.

job_title: ECE Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Challenging, as the undergraduate teaching assistant, you learn new knowledge, and debugging skill as well while helping other student debugging their homework.
All professors I have work with are very respectful, and nice.
The pay might not be much, but the experience is unique, especially if you are the person who like to help others.
cons: The hourly pay could be better. The hourly salary for a senior student teaching assistant is only 10 dollar per hour.

review_title: Great people and fantastic place to work
pros: Cutting edge of technology, constant growth, student and staff are very engaging. Vacation and sick leave are great. There is a good state retirement program with a 10 year vest.
cons: Salaries and raises are not the same as you find it the private sector. Parking on campus is expensive. Depending on the position not a lot of room for growth.

pros:
I had a great manager whose main focus was to provide a positive atmosphere for employees
Easygoing environment
Great pay and benefits
cons: None that I can think of. It was just a great place to work. Okay, we had to pay for parking, but not much!

review_title: Good for a part time / research position while you're studying at Tech for your Masters or PhD.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech provides you with whatever you need, helps you balance work and study.
cons: The pay isn't as high as it could really be but that's expected for a research assistant's job.

review_title: Great school with an unfortunate amount of red tape
pros: The people are great. Being in downtown Atlanta is also a big plus. Easy access to MARTA and the airport, 30 minutes to airport. Being in the south, there is a bit of a culture shock coming from New York.
cons: Red tape everywhere. Hard to make changes due to being a public school. Bud Peterson is slowly but surely destroying the little fun that is left at this school.

pros: I worked as a student developer and cannot complain of the experience.  Hours were flexible.  Pay was fair for a starting part-time developer position during the school year.  HR was agreeable and helpful whenever possible.
cons: Largely employing students for part-time developer positions yielded significant turnover and some goals/objectives were lost during the transition process.  It is to be expected though as that's why I chose to work here.

pros: Good Retirement Fund and Benefits
cons: Don't have a degree higher than your manager, or you will have issues with their insecurities

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent connections with industry and otherwise. Lots of resources and equipment if you know who and how to ask. Looks great on a resume.
cons: Getting and keeping funding for projects can be difficult. Working with professors is rewarding but it is easy to get stepped on.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
-provide stipend for breaks (still paid over winter break)
-direct deposit available
-clear job training
-research hours flexible
-HR was incredibly helpful throughout
cons:
-student fees cut into stipend
-flexible hours can mean more than 20 hours of work in a week nearing deadlines, but this varies

pros: It was fairly easy work and you set your own hours. If you are efficient you can make effectively make about $20 per hour.
cons: Systems for payroll were changed. New system was bad and took several attempts to get paid at end of semester.

pros:
Campus is located very close to Midtown Atlanta, so, you have a nice view of the city from campus.
The ranking of each engineering department is among top 10 in the U.S.
You have great opportunities after graduation. Almost every company is excited to hire recent graduates of Georgia tech.
cons: The PhD qualifying exam of some departments like ME is very difficult and you need to put at least two months preparation for the exam.

pros: Rigorous, intense learning atmosphere is definitely the hallmark Georgia Tech. Meanwhile, the plethora of student associations and clubs also help diversifies my college experience.
cons: We are not pleased with the campus dining service, to say the least. Instructional equipments and facilities are great, but when it comes to campus residential hall living standard, it definitely doesn't reach the bar.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Free education and the opportunity to study any subject on campus while getting paid to obtain a degree
cons: The lab that I was in was run more as a company than as a school. There were about 150+ graduate students for one professor, which means that the amount of contact hours was actually too low and it was really hard to get an appointment

pros: Co-workers and students are great.
cons: The new management teams practice Jim Crow!

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Working as a graduate teaching assistant was a very beneficial experience. Teaching entry level class improved my understanding of the basics, and it also helped me with my communication skills.
cons: Can't really think of anything I'm not satisfied with. The training before the begging of the semester was very intense. I understand the benefits of "learning to teach", but most people just didn't care much about it.

review_title: Typical graduate school experience, probably, very competitive and lots of work and uncertainty
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Highly-ranked departments, lots of research funding available, stable environment in tough economic times, Atlanta is a great city, education is a very gratifying field. Collaboration/Joint Department with Emory Medical School is very promising.
cons: government bureaucracy can be discouraging from time to time, international reputation is still in the early stages due to being a public school located in the South.

pros: Georgia Tech is on the forefront of many science technologies. Other than interacting with some of the brightest minds in Computer Science, I also formed connections with many colleagues and was put into contact with many top hiring companies for after Graduation.
cons: Although I was only a Teaching Assistant, the tech work ethic is very demanding. Doing an additional 15-20 hours of work on top of 5 classes was rather challenging.

review_title: Caring group of people looking to help the kids
pros:
As an All Kids Count tutor, you are told upfront and reminded over and over that it is all about the kids, which I found very reassuring since I'm so used to tutoring gigs being more about just an 'easy' after school job. 
You create your own schedule and are paid higher than other tutors on campus.
cons: There really weren't any cons. I loved it!

review_title: Digital Humanities & Green Humanities at Tech
job_title: Marion L Brittain Postdoctoral Fellow in Atlanta, GA
pros: A wonderful place to develop intellectually; good opportunities for exploring interdisciplinary thinking. My salary increased 30% over the two years that I worked here.
cons: No research library and limited archives. Materials requests had to be conducted entirely through GIL or ILL which created a lot of challenges for keeping up to date on new trends in the field and conducting research. A very limited research budget ($300).

review_title: Great place to work for grad school. Moderate pay for engineering grad students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is well set up to take in external money and process it properly. School chairs are very willing to go out of there way to make it work for you. Generally you can set your own schedule
cons: Salary was low. Insurance is poor. While you can set your own schedule, they often demand long hours.

pros: Very interesting research projects, budgets made by the NSF, great students very communicative and in an excellent location. I love it!
cons: The ratio is pretty bad not enough girls around. This forces you to go out in Atlanta to find girls ha ha ha just kidding. Don't think there are any cons

job_title: Research Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: top 10 research institution in the us with an excellent wealth of resources to investigate cutting edge technology. brilliant colleagues, lots of good opportunities for research and professional development.
cons: located in the heart of atlanta, horrible (reliable) public transportation options. additionally the on-campus theft rate is ridiculous - students and/or people off the street entering and stealing equipment in broad daylight.

pros: Good environment, helpful and supportive faculty and staff. A good working research environment and a lot of supportive programs to assist when performing attendant duties. i.e. TA
cons: Inflexible Administrative policies with the main university, less so with the specific colleges. Difficult to find information to resolve administrative problems.

pros: World class education. Accepting of students/GRA's  with more diverse backgrounds than many other top programs. Research options are diverse and still growing.
cons: The core training curriculum is too rigid, and inconsistent with the diversity of students being brought in. It's not a one-size-fits-all scenario, please recognize it as such and allow us to address our unique deficiencies.

review_title: Good Place to Work when State Budgets are Adequate
pros: Great reputation, dynamic faculty, interesting research, good service orientation, good benefits package so far.  New President seems quite good, wants to do a new strategic plan to position Georgia Tech for the next 10-20 years.
cons: Students can be on the conservative side, state budgets, library budget never big enough even in good economic times.

pros:
The prestige of working at GT carries a lot of weight with future employees--in higher ed, at least.
The intown location is awesome.
cons: There are raise and promotion freezes right now.  It seems like some departments know how to get around this while others leave you hanging

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Being a teaching assistant was a great experience. I highly recommend it to anyone who is good at math and likes to teach. The pay is very good considering how easy it is to fit into your schedule - it's basically just like taking another class.
cons: Some professors may not communicate with the TAs sufficiently, making your job more difficult. Grading papers is a boring but necessary part of the job.

pros: Great campus, great athletic facility, nice sports teams to root for, great access to the best parts of Atlanta.
cons: Stipend depends on department, but student fees are ~ $3000 per year including health insurance. It is common for schools to have high fees these days though. Also, crime rate in Atlanta is not the best.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Working on interesting material that hasn't been studied before.
Access to a lot of great resources and equipment.
Work-life balance generally varies between groups, but most find time to enjoy life outside of the lab.
cons: Cons are generally advisor dependent, but for the most part you will be working a full-time job on top of going to class, TAing, and doing some other duties. You need to be able to manage your time.

pros: Georgia Tech is a good employer. Georgia Tech is located in Midtown Atlanta, which is a great area. Campus culture is good.
cons: Traffic is bad and the campus is still in development. Campus culture is good but can use some more improvement.

review_title: Love the school, but as a GRA it is stressful and your advisor makes or breaks you.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: You have a lot of resources at you disposal and many leaders in your field that will help. Atlanta has a lot of things to spend free time doing.
cons: Very long hours depending on your research advisor. Funding is variable year to year. So job security is not a definite, especially in the current economy (2012).

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Atlanta, GA
pros: Top research institution with endless opportunities. Overall working atmosphere is fantastic in a truly international atmosphere.
cons:
- Work life balance is not as good as the rankings in 'Best Colleges to for for' say.
- The administration procedures are a mess (e.g. approval of international grant applications)

review_title: Great Job if you find a Niche!
job_title: Research Engineer I in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexible work environment, Great Benefits, Stable. This is a great job for an experienced professional because GT appreciates a self starter.
cons: Hard to move up, low promotion rate, if you don't become a SME quickly you'll find yourself without a job. New grads need not apply however you are more likely to get a job but it won't last long if youre not a self starter.

pros: In the cardiovascular fluid mechanics laboratory, one is surrounded by doctors and graduate students pursuing their phDs. It is a very supportive, collaborative work environment.
cons: Unless you are pursuing your phD, it is very difficult to secure a full time position in the laboratory.

pros: Great Education, fun projects, great people. Hard work, but very fulfilling. There is a reason it holds some of the top programs in the country
cons: There is a lack of assistantships available. In fact, usually only PhDs get them. This makes the cost of attendance quite expensive

review_title: Enjoyable working experience in Georgia Tech
pros: Georgia Tech has good academic reputation, well recognized in the country. The location is good and the cost of living in Atlanta is not very high. The salary is good taking into account the cost of living in Atlanta. Staffs are very professional.
cons:
Not super prestigious like MIT
Parking on campus is kinda expensive
Not very safe to walk around at night alone in the city

pros: Free Housing, small stipend, and a lot of opportunities to meet new people. First access to maintenance when needed. Also, the free housing is usually in a good location.
cons: Housing charges a ton for rooms and they know it and they don't care. Stipend is small considering how much some people work, and if anything meals should also be included.

review_title: Average to say the least, I have work of more than one employer and I was able to make a whole lot more money in return
job_title: Preventive Maintenance Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Jobs at GA Tech are stable jobs.
cons: Job titles do not necessary match compensation, perhaps the educational job market is less lucrative than private job.

review_title: Great place to work and study at the same time.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The best part about being a graduate Teaching Assistant at Gerogia Tech is that you have flexible hours of work. Georgia Tech is a great place of all round development and pursuing interests
cons: Being a graduate Teaching Assistant, I feel that Gerogia Tech has a very hectic time schedule. If you do not plan and organize your time carefully, you will lag behind.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: To be able to work on the research area that you are interested. To do cutting-edge research in a group of bright people.
cons: Bad work-life balance of graduate students. Exam weeks. Research project deadlines or paper deadlines tend to be pretty hectic times.

pros: Decent Pay, generally good students and good coworkers. Fun environment. I've had a good experience at Georgia Tech so far and intend to continue working for them.
cons: Not much room for growth. A high volume of coworkers doesn't allow for much upward movement. Other than that, not much else to say.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: There's a lot of funded projects. There are experts from all fields that you could potentially ask advice from. Lots of hardware to do stuff with
cons: Often the professors don't care about the workload. Funding is almost never guaranteed and people get stranded all the time

pros: GT allows undergraduate students to work, you can be a TA, and the first semester you will get credit but the other semesters you'll be paid between 8 - 10 dollars per hour working. It's ok work, not that impressive really. You have to submit a weekly timesheet.
cons: If you are an undergraduate researcher you only get paid about $8 - $10 hour.

review_title: Georgia Tech provides great networking opportunities.
pros: Georgia Tech is a global leader in education and research. There are many opportunities to network with people and businesses. Many successful companies regularly visit to recruit.
cons: Georgia Tech has a very competitive atmosphere that may be difficult to handle. You must be willing to work hard and have the ability to teach yourself new things very quickly.

pros: Being a Teaching Assistant was a great experience. I got to help my fellow students learn challenging material and I reinforced my own knowledge. I also got to connect and network with the professors I worked for.
cons: No real complaints. Sometimes you have to get things like tests, quizzes, homework graded by a certain dead line, but if you manage your time well, it is doable.

pros: Professors are all very helpful and they want you to success. You can chose courses from different departments pretty easy and even transferred to another major.
cons: Some courses are too heavy loaded. Too many quizzes. Also, some course, for example, CS 4761, has more than 300 people in a room for one class. This is not that efficient.

review_title: For grad students, you only get $1000 per month for all your expenses
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Academically it is fine. They have decent research fundings, and the research enviornment is  good , you learn a lot . I would recommend it.
cons: Salaries are little low and I am looking to get out of here as soon as possible. I want more challenging jobs and more salary and more to life than this.

pros:
Great environment,
smart students,
smart professors,
great researches,
many internships,
Overall, I think it is a great place to be at if you want to meet many great people and engineers in specific.
cons:
Everyone seems really busy,
not my favorite city,
I really don't see many cons in here, except for the whole idea that most people are really busy and you don't really get the chance to meet new people because of that

pros: A lot of responsibility,  good future career connections, helpful mentors who will assist you in future classes and industry happenings
cons: Pay for undergraduate assistants is minimum wage (obviously), and the course load is challenging, so grading can be tough. But overall a great experience

pros: Great education I learned so much while I was at GT it was a amazing experience would do it again
cons: Difficult hours. As a student you have to stay up and study so you can be prepared for classes and that can be hard.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent infrastructure. Lots of employee support and resources for graduate students. Free rec center access is a big plus.
cons: Insane student fees (~$1400/term, with the option to be deducted from your paycheck over 3 months.) If there is any sort of payroll error, it is a huge pain to get it fixed and can sometimes take weeks. Not ideal on a grad student salary.

review_title: Georgia Tech is an excellent place to work.
job_title: Corporate Relations Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is a world class university. The students are motivated and very smart. Atlanta is an ideal location. I highly recommend Georgia Tech as a place to work.
cons: Sometimes decisions take longer than in a business environment. Academics are not used as to managing people  and non performing individuals may not be addressed as quickly as in a business environment.

review_title: Research Associate: Aerospace Systems Design Lab
pros: Challenging work environment where you are engaged in a variety of engineering topics and come in contact with a number of industry and government partners
cons: Can be placed on undesirable projects and work with individuals who are not motivated to complete the assigned tasks

review_title: Great place to work; great benefits.
pros: benefits. the ability to work with students and high achievers. My salary was considerably lower than others with my title but I understand and support the reasoning
cons: we'll not know how the new administration will be. some unknowns as of now. My salary was considerably lower than others with my title but I understand and support the reasoning

job_title: Residential Technical Advisor in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Fairly laid back and super understanding management
Decent amounts of downtime
Flexible work hours
Interesting work when out in the field
Very nice as an on campus student job
cons:
Disorganization at the management level
Low pay for services provided
As it's tier one support, a lot of the job is dealing with very simple problems

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant (AE) in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Excellent education opportunity and research facilities.

Connections with industry will help with the job hunt later on.

Respected institution
cons:
Low pay compared with industry
-I understand that this is an educational opportunity, but most GRAs I know work far more than the expected "20 hrs" a week. Even including tuition, this is not a very sustainable income in Metro Atlanta.

Long hours when combined with classwork (I worked most weekends).

pros:
Supervisors are very accomodating for schoolwork
You choose how hard you make your workload
The position is sometimes regarded with respect
cons:
Doesn't really help as resume fodder for a technical person
Much of the management culture is simply out of touch with Tech culture

review_title: Campus Recreational Center Aquatics Facility - Instructor, Head Lifeguard
job_title: Instructor, Head Lifeguard in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexible hours - not too difficult to trade shifts - can work schedule between/before/after classes. Ellis CPR/First Aid classes appear more professional and reliable than most Red Cross & YMCA certification classes. Opportunities to become instructor or pool operator (AFO certification).
cons: May be difficult to get more than 15 hours if only a lifeguard and not head/supervisor or instructor

pros: Get to know a wide range of your piers. Help residents get more involved in community. Free housing and a stipend. Housing staff is very friendly and love what they do!
cons: A pretty decent time commitment. Going "on duty" can interfere with your vacation / holiday plans and can also get you into some sticky situations that you have to address with residents.

pros: Relatively easy to get an on campus job, especially convenient for when taking classes. Shift scheduling was relatively flexible.
cons: With my specific job I was never able to take time from my shifts to get some schoolwork done (which other positions were allowed to do), which sometimes led to me getting behind on schoolwork. This could have been avoided had I applied for a different position.

pros: Georgia Tech offers highly challenging and exciting opportunities because of the number of interdisciplinary projects involved. Having tie-ups with industries add to its value.
cons: The major downside is the emphasis on a lot of coursework in the very first semester of school. Can be avoided.

pros: The university is full of clever and intellectual people which makes is a great place to be in. The city is fine as well.
cons: Everyone is working too much and many times there is not much time for human relationships such as going to lunch etc...

pros: Top technical institute in science, technology and engineering. Compared to best in the world. Top class well known faculty to advise.
cons: I don't see any downsides of working at Georgia Tech except that the salaries may not be competitive but the selection is tough.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Resources are boundless, professors are some of the smartest in the world in their respective fields. Advisors are willing to help you get to wherever you want to be.
cons:
Traffic in Atlanta can be a bit messy :)

Seriously though, there aren't many things bad about this place as long as you're working in a lab where you really get into the subject matter.

job_title: Temporary Part-Time Instructor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Taught for study abroad program. Lots of opportunities to teach around the world. Students are smart and ambitious. Material is challenging. Living costs covered.
cons: Pay was only decent, though many of the living costs were covered. Classes were really hard for full-term, let alone abbreviated semesters, so students had a hard time.

pros: Good environment, sound workplace. The people are nice, and they know what they're doing. As long as you have a goal, you'll be fine.
cons: The salary isn't very competitive. Considering it is a college, you can expect that, but still it was pretty low.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Easy to find a suitable mentor amongst extensive faculty for Ph.D or Masters Thesis
- Funds available for conference travel and reimbursed appropriately
- Access to high quality equipment and lab techs to assist with usage
cons:
- area around Tech not suitable for walking at night alone
- commute to work can be bothersome with traffic
- parking permits are expensive.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: All the professors I've worked with have really cared about their TAs and the students they're teaching. They respect both parties and are genuinely interested in teaching.
cons: One major challenges it the lack of motivation of some students, especially in the introductory classes. It makes sense given that they're not going to major in biology but it's still tough to work with.

pros: I like it is a nice environment, the campus is nice. Lost of opportunities upon graduation. I like it a lot.
cons: lots of work no time frame, working more than full time, you have to be careful with balance with life.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
One of the Best Schools in the World.
Very supportive staff and management.
Great venue for learning.
Multicultural.
Great chances of growth.
Chance to Network with some of the leading people in your fields of interest.
cons: I will say I did not see any that I can mention.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant, Chemistry in Atlanta, GA
pros: There are a lot of collaborations and resources available for graduate students in the chemistry department at Georgia Tech. Overall, professors are friendly and accessible when it comes to interacting with students.
cons: Due to the size, there are many inconsistencies in program requirements depending on what lab one joins. These can be very frustrating when everyone in the program receives the same degree.

review_title: Great PhD Program, but requires a significant amount of work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Getting a PhD in engineering from an elite engineering university.
cons: Be prepared to spend all (10+ hours a day at least 6 days a week) your time here if you want to graduate in less than 5 years.

review_title: Materials Science and Engineering Grad Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
International research environment (work with some of the best in the world)
Great access to industry - several career fair opportunities
Can find a lot of equipment for research on campus (may require collaboration with another group)
High level of expertise among several fields (diverse research)
cons:
High-stress environment
High level of competition (not necessarily a con though)
Administration heavy institution 
Low pay (fees required)

pros: I worked at Georgia Tech in CEISMC, I felt like my work was meaningful and my research did make an impact on with the students I worked with.
cons: As a part time employee, there are no benefits (even sick days), and I felt like my work wasn't really valued by other members of the department. The pay is lower than for private industry jobs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Prestigious university
Lots of industry/government contacts
Flexible Hours
Cutting edge research
Highly qualified coworkers
Good job prospects upon graduation .
cons:
